name: dfsb7OLD
params: setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, wff w0
body: |- wb(wsb(s0, s1, w0), wex(s2, wa(wceq(cv(s2), cv(s0)), wex(s1, wa(wceq(cv(s1), cv(s2)), w0)))))

body.origin:
|- wb(wsb(s0, s1, w0), wex(s2, wa(wceq(cv(s2), cv(s0)), wex(s1, wa(wceq(cv(s1), cv(s2)), w0)))))
-| wnf(s2, w0)
-| diffss(s0, s2)

cumulated.origin:
|- wb(wsb(s0, s1, w0), wex(s2, wa(wceq(cv(s2), cv(s0)), wex(s1, wa(wceq(cv(s1), cv(s2)), w0)))))
-| wnf(s2, w0)
-| diffss(s0, s2)

|- wb(wsb(s0, s1, w0), wex(s2, wa(wceq(cv(s2), cv(s0)), wex(s1, wa(wceq(cv(s1), cv(s2)), w0)))))
-| diffss(s0, s2)
-| diffsw(s2, w0)

comment: Obsolete version of ~ dfsb7 as of 8-Jul-2023. An alternate definition of proper substitution ~ df-sb . By introducing a dummy variable ` z ` in the definiens, we are able to eliminate any distinct variable restrictions among the variables ` x ` , ` y ` , and ` ph ` of the definiendum. No distinct variable conflicts arise because ` z ` effectively insulates ` x ` from ` y ` . To achieve this, we use a chain of two substitutions in the form of ~ sb5 , first ` z ` for ` x ` then ` y ` for ` z ` . Compare Definition 2.1'' of [Quine] p. 17, which is obtained from this theorem by applying ~ df-clab . Theorem ~ sb7h provides a version where ` ph ` and ` z ` don't have to be distinct. (Contributed by NM, 28-Jan-2004.) (Proof modification is discouraged.) (New usage is discouraged.)
